segments.text: Okay.
Because of personality defects, a few people didn't get along very well with them.
And interestingly enough, the Venezuelan officers pretty much expected perfection from us, although they'd accept less for themselves.
I thought that was an interesting relationship.
If you really applied yourself in trying to help them and doing the job you were there to do, they appreciated it and they respected you for it.
They had the idea that some of the people were there to enjoy their life rather than work.
But some of the Americans were.
Some of the Americans, but that's not really true.
What really happened, this personality thing worked both ways, but
There were a few cases in which Venezuelan commanders simply didn't want this advisor around for whatever reason.
And so they became ineffective because they weren't accepted, not because of personality or anything of the sort.
They just didn't want that advice or help or interference, however they looked upon it.
And it was easy to be put in a position of interference.
you know, tried not to distinguish, and that almost got me in trouble one time, but basically I think it was sound.
Okay, will you tell me about that one time?
Well, I would just say very briefly that, yes, I won't go into detail, but in my core, in the course of my learning Spanish, I also picked up colloquialisms, and
It's interesting that in Spanish, and I suppose this to some degree is true in English, but these colloquialisms mean different things to different people depending on what country you're from.
I know Venezuelans who come in to me, they were very careful when they went to Mexico of how they used certain terms because they meant different things.
Some of them bugger it.
And I also learned after the fact that
some of their colloquialism used in common, ordinary conversation under certain circumstances is very damaging.
And I was guilty of doing that.

He said, he thought, an officer thought that I'd insulted him by using such a colloquialism when I was, appeared to be angry to him, which was under such circumstances, if intentional, would have been an insult.
Anyway, he made an official complaint that resulted in an investigation that, because he'd complained, it had to be reported formally.
And I was completely exonerated as having been not at all intentional in misusing that word.
In fact, didn't understand it.
And to a man, the Venezuelan officers that testified supported
my innocence.
And I, of course, appreciate that because I think that's a little bit difficult to do when a foreign officer's involved.
And it turned out not to be a big thing, but it did bother me a great deal at the time.
And it could have been damaging for your career.
It could have been very damaging, as it was.
I wish I had asked for a copy of that report because that would have probably been...
of more value in my file than the efficiency report I got from my boss, as it were.
Because the Venezuelans supported you so much.
Yeah.
Then we left there.
Well, I was wondering, before we leave there, is that school still in existence?
It is, and as a matter of fact, my wife and I, Fran and I, were invited back ten years later as guests to the Venezuelan Army to observe the tenth
year observance of the formation of that school.
We were asked to stay for a month, and we stayed, I think, ten days.
We were just royally treated.
They did have a fine ceremony.
Incidentally, Lieutenant Colonel Quevedo, who was the first commandant at this point, was commander-in-chief of the Army.
of Venezuela.

And interestingly enough, when Prez Jimnez, the dictator, was kicked out in, I believe it was 1954, Coveto was one of the three-man junta that reorganized the government, decreed the Constitutional Convention that set up the present
government form under the present Constitution, which provided for two houses of Congress, a president serving a five-year tour.
In other words, our basic pattern of the executive legislative judicial got a commitment from the armed forces.
The Minister of Defense proclaimed that never again would the Venezuelan armed forces be used against the government, only to support the government.
And they're now in their fifth five-year presidency without interruption or serious incident.
Incidentally, General Collado became a senator.
He did?
After he retired from the Army in this system that he helped create.
And I consider him a patriot.
What kind of man is Govedo?
Oh, he's a fine man.
He's very likable and very personal.

Just from his physical appearance, and I don't know this to be the case, but I would say he's half Indian, or he's got a lot of Indian blood in him, but he's a good native son, and he was a very effective and popular officer, and obviously able to handle
the high position of responsibility that he found himself in as a member of the governing junta.
Was he from a wealthy family?
No.
Most of the Venezuelan officers are not from wealthy families.
Some are.
Many of them, of course, their social status is improved by going through the academy and becoming an officer.
I went to Venezuela on business a couple of times in about 1975 and 1977, I guess it was.
On that return in 1975, I had a wonderful experience of recontacting many of these officers.
My very best friend that I made there was Enrique Pea Briseo.
He was a lieutenant when I arrived in Venezuela, and he became a general officer.
And so we had a good reunion there.
I'd had a reunion with him in Washington and Rome in the intervening years.
We maintained this friendship, he and others.
But he was my best Venezuelan friend.
Anyway, most of those officers in that first class that I conducted became general officers.
It was remarkable.

And as a matter of fact, when I went back there in 75, General Cabello was then retired, and he hosted a reception, cocktail reception, for me, and invited all of these people and their wives that he could get in touch with.
And it was just a wonderful reunion.
Of course, we'd done this
on that ten year anniversary too, so you can see the continuity has been maintained rather surprisingly well.
Now there were a couple of events that were very important on the international scene when you were in Venezuela.
One was the Korean War.
Did you want to go to the war?
Did you volunteer?
No, I didn't volunteer.
I arrived in Venezuela six months before that war started.
I left there in 1952 and all of the intensive purchases were over.
We have in the Army what you call a stabilized tour.
In other words, you're sent there and you won't be moved until that tour is completed.
But this was a peculiar one in Venezuela.
We were under contract with the Venezuelan Army.
As a matter of fact, the Venezuelan Army paid me, in addition to my Army pay, $250,000.
$87 a month.
What that was was not a salary, that was a cost of living differential, but it was kind of a hold on us, you see, and a contract with us.
So, I was in effect pinned down there those three years.
Of course, one of the major events in recent military history was the firing of General MacArthur.
What did you think of Truman's action?
I'm a great admirer of General MacArthur's, and I think he's one of the greatest generals we ever produced.
He's one of the greatest strategists we've ever produced.
I felt President Truman was correct.
He had to do what he did.
Very simple.
After all, he's commander-in-chief.
If it had been MacArthur and him,
Lieutenant General down below him had been the same thing.
Anytime a subordinate cannot accept the policy direction of his superior, he's got to resign or get fired, one or the other.
He got fired.
I never had any question about it, much as I regretted it.
Okay.
Let's move on now.
After this, you went to student at the U.S. Command and General Staff College from August 1952 to July 1953.
This is a very important event in your career advancement, isn't it?
It is.
And that's probably the most useful school training that I received in the Army.
And I did attend, of course, the artillery school and the war college as well.
in some special schools.
But anyway You thought it was more important than the War College?
I do, and I'll tell you why.
Good.
It was very demanding of time.
Incidentally, our second child daughter was born at Leavenworth.
Our first child son was born in Venezuela.
I thought of that because I had so little time to enjoy our baby daughter.
I was so busy.
Our son, by the way, had a dual citizenship, and he had to make a choice at the age of eighteen, according to Venezuelan law.
And, of course, the choice was easy, the choice of citizenship.
The Command and General Staff College prepares officers for general staff work at all levels, and it prepares him for command of
units through the division and corps.
You know, we have the company battalion, regiment, or brigade, brigade now, division, corps, and field army.
Well, this brought the students through the division and corps phase of planning and commanding.
It was very demanding, the very
because we were always moving at a pace that you could never quite finish the race before, today's race, before the bar starts.
And it was planned that way.
And it's rather disconcerting, but it's surprising after it's all over how much of that exposure you retain.
But it was just an excellent, very best instruction, too, quality-wise.
But it, I felt, prepared me for just about any job that I'd be assigned in the Army.
It gave me a good base to begin any assignment in the Army.
How would you compare that with two years later when you went to the Army War College?
Well, it was two assignments later that I went to the Army War College.
August 1956 to November 1950.
Well, the War College, I think they're very complementary, but if I had to choose one as being the most important, the most valuable to me, it was the Command Staff College.
The War College, on the other hand, is the level at which you study national strategy and military strategy.
So you see, it complements, it picks up basically where the Command Staff College leaves off, and that's the way it's designed.
I thought the experience in the War College was invaluable.
It was the first time
since I entered the Army, that I and my contemporaries who sat with me there had the opportunity, the time, and the environment to really think policy strategy.
Now, strange as it may seem, if you're on the road that far,
you're always so, or I was always so committed to the job that you just had to deal with what was at hand, you know.
Sure.
So it was a wonderful experience.
We used seminars and committees and lectures, and there was plenty of time for individual thought and committee and contribution to the committee work.
And we'd treat with a series of,

aspects of national and military strategy policy and strategy through the year and so it was just a very fine rounding of uh for example i left uh between leavenworth the command staff college and the war cars i went to the pentagon that's my first full tour on the army staff and i was in a position there to

to observe this policy and strategy in action because I wound up as assistant executive officer to the chief planning officer of the Army, planning and operations officer of the Army, the G3, General James Gavin at the time I joined that office.
And, of course, never had in the course of my job to reallyand it wasn't my position toto really
making my own judgment on some of these things that were so important to the Army and the nation.
But when I got to the War College, then we were told to look at these things, and particularly look to the future.
Sure.
And make up, get our own convictions.
You asked me in conversation if I thought it was practical to have tactical, use tactical nuclear weapons in war.
Mm-hmm.
I came to the conclusion as a student at War College that it's going to be done someday.
The question is, where does this nuclear exchange stop?
I can't see, for example, the U.S. Army in Europe and its NATO allies accepting initial defeat by the Russians
should they ever decide to make a conventional attack.
I can't see them accepting initial defeat forward and give up East Germany because- I mean West Germany.
I mean West Germany because there's no stopping point then once that West Germany is breached that I can see.

think rather than accept such a defeat that we would use nuclear weapons which could stop the advance of those forces because of the geography and character of the terrain that they've got to come over but at the same time they're then going to bring them into play and where does this stop and that is what gives credence to the deterrence of these vast nuclear weapons we have that that i say must never be used

So I guess rather than hoping, I'm reasoning that we will have effective deterrents, because it's unthinkable that we would let the use of small tactical nuclear weapons evolve into increasing exchanges that wind up with an exchange of thermonuclear weapons.
It's suicide.
These are the types of issues that you discuss.
Those are the types of issues that we discuss.
Plus, for example, at the War College.
I remember another one.
I came to the conclusion, and each has his own opportunity, you know, make his own conclusions, that we should make our peace with Communist China.
We could not hope to survive a concerted, joint,

opposition militarily or between China and Russia against us joint their joint undertaking against us they could overrun the vast areas of the world that are so important to us that it would reduce us to to unimportance but we better see to it that through the United Nations or otherwise we get this fester of hormosis settled
And the best way seemed to be to get Formosa declared an independent nation with some name other than China.
Formosa wasn't China before the Communists took over.
They were a province of China.
Chiang Kai-shek made it China.
Well, this never happened, so you see where we are now.
We have made our peace with China,
but we haven't resolved that matter of Formosa, and that will always be a debit on our account until it's settled.
That's just another example.
Let's go to the Pentagon.
This is the first chance you had to move into the Pentagon.
This is the hub of the military, and you moved there in July 1953 and stayed until August 1956 in two different jobs.
Let's describe those jobs to begin with.
Staff officer, organization and training division, office of assistant chief of staff.
Yes.
Of course, the function of the army general staff was to establish the policies for the army, promulgate the policies for the army.
do the planning for the Army, overall planning, and the budgeting for the resources of the Army, procurement there of those resources.
In the training field, which I was in initially, we basically set training policy in that shop.
We developed training policy to be promulgated by the Army Chief of Staff and Secretary of the Army.
And this had to do with, at the time,
Training sounds like a simple term, and it is, because in the course of our career, most of our time spent training.
The interesting thing at the time, of course, was training in nuclear weapons.
They were new to us.
We still, in 1953, had not become accustomed to them, so that was one of the challenges, nuclear training.
Of course, this is the time that the American Armed Forces are still having above-atmosphere bomb testing.
Were you in any way involved with those tests?
I was involved in the planning for them, yes, but I was never on site.
Actually, one thing I wanted to do was to get on site and observe this nuclear weapon.
I never had the opportunity.
Of course, at that time, now we're reflecting, of course, on the
The radiation.
The radiation that may have been lasting effects, which are affecting the health of people who were there, and I'm sure that more is going to be learned of that.
At the time, safety was a very, very important aspect of it, of course, and the extreme precautions were taken to shield the people.
And, of course, safety is always primary in
Well, just shooting artillery, for example, for practice.
But I'm sure that, obviously, we've learned a lot about them since that we didn't know then.
Now, I don't know really how to evaluate this problem because I've never seen the data on what we know now versus what we knew then on the penetration of this radiation.
We were just in the exploratory phase as far as nuclear weapons and as far as
We had to learn.
We had to learn more about this weapon, this family of weapons.
And I thought at the time that these were very forward actions being taken, you know, and courageous in many ways to undertake those tests like we did to find out more about it.
Now, what those dangers were, as we look back in retrospect, we're going to know more about, I'm sure, in short order.

I believe the state and the legislature and the federal government have both recently passed bills that are going to create the resources to not only treat the people who've been affected, you know, to help them with their problem of treatment, and the Agent Orange people from Vietnam
but also to study this more carefully so that we learn more.
Well, in the last few years in the news, during the 1970s especially, some journalists and other commentators have charged that the Army was using their troops as guinea pigs.
What's your opinion of those charges?
Why don't we put that into English-specific terms?
What's a guinea pig?
Well, using human soldiers out there for experiments.
I think that to some extent that was true because we were conducting those tests to see what the blast effects were on structures and troops.
military equipment, what the heat effects were, what the radiation effects were.
And I'm sure that to some extent that was the purpose of those troops being there.
The other purpose was that they become, shall we say, oriented to some degree in what this really is.
But the Army felt that it had to start, of course, positioning troops at an absolutely safe distance to measure the effects and not go closer than would be considered safe.
Now, I'm sure if what is being implied that they were deliberately put into unsafe areas to see what the effects would be, that is not true.
I think it's entirely possible that they were put into a position that was considered to be safe
But the knowledge at the time led him to a bad judgment.
What other types of testing besides nuclear, because you were an expert in artillery, were you also in charge of that at the Pentagon?
No, being an artilleryman had nothing to do with mine.
I was a general staff officer expected to handle any subject in my field.
But you ask what else.
At that time, of course, we were preparing an artillery nuclear weapon.
At that time, we also were developing advanced chemical weapons.
These are the tedious ones that come to mind.
How successful were you in these developments?
That's one of the things about serving in the Pentagon that is a bit frustrating.
What you do there is seldom, particularly in the areas of planning and strategy, of course, the effects of what you've done is seldom seen within a matter of the time you're there.
It's probably after you leave that the impact is really visible.
That's particularly true in developments of new things.
For example, I just read this morning in one of my military magazines that the field artillery's computerized fire direction system is now being deployed throughout the Army.
When I was at Fort Selle in 1961 as chief of
research and the development organization.
We initiated that research on that specific system.
And we developed computer programs to try out on commercial computers, because we didn't have any in the Army.
And do you know that that was twenty years ago?
Sure.
That's an example of how long it takes to really realize what you started in development.
It shouldn't have taken that long, I might add, and I think it's disgraceful that it did.
And I think the major element in that is decision time.
Do you think the Pentagon works too slowly, then?
Without question.
Why is that?
I'm not a reactionary.
I don't think we could go back to the old ways of doing things and do them better.
But some of the principles that applied then certainly apply now.

If we'd go back to the year that I entered the Army, 1941, the development of that computer system or its counterpart in those days would have been in the province of the chief of field artillery on the Army staff.
And he would have made the basic decisions on it.
And when he said, I've got something that's ready, the Chief of Staff of the Army and the Secretary of the Army would have made the final decision on it.
And that would entail then the proper program, budget, and money to buy it, develop it and buy it.
Today, the Secretary of Defense makes that decision.
It's ridiculous.
And when you count the Secretary of Defense or his deputies,

When you count the treatment then of this problem between the guys at Fort Sill who are trying to develop this for the user in the field, or trying to get the requirements stated and get it developed, and count the contacts and the actions between him now under the present system and the Office of the Secretary of Defense, it's absolutely miraculous that anything ever gets out.
It's the most disappointing thing, and by the way, we'll get down the line, I was in the development business as a major general before I went to the Pentagon as chief legislative liaison.
And it's one of the most disappointing things in my service to see how encumbered we are.
And it's a result of putting the dollar focus first on everything.
Certainly you can't
You can't ignore the dollar.
God knows we can't afford the dollars we really need to prepare.

But when you put the decisions on weapons and weapon-supporting systems, materiel, in the hands of civilians, I'm not questioning civilian authority, they can only think in terms of dollars because they don't understand the weapon system.
Really.
Really.
how this is going to be used and what the real need is.
And we're going to have to return to the principle that the user, the guy in uniform, has got the loudest voice and what is going to be produced for him or we're going to be in real trouble.
We're already in real trouble.
Now I'm critical of some of that CBS program recently on national security of the United States, but they pointed up some of these points.
What was the difference between your first job from July 53 to April 54 and then April 54 to August 56 when you were shifted to assistant executive officer?
What was the difference in that?
assistant executive officer.
Well, it's very different.
And if you'd like, I'll outline what the assistant executive officer is.
I was assistant to the executive officer.
The executive officer was a colonel, and he's the man in the office of the assistant chief of staff, G-3.
We had four general officers up there, the G-3 and three assistants.
And that colonel
was the fellow that they turned to to get this done or bring me this kind of advice and so forth.
He was really his, you might say, if you could think of it, his chief of staff.
The G3's chief of staff.
And I was the assistant chief of staff in those terms.
This meant that all this whole area of responsibility of training, operations, plans came to a focus at this office.
And therefore, much of these actions, of course, are handled on paper and in specific formats.
As a matter of fact, when a paper is put on one of those generous desks, the whole story is on the top sheet in summary.
Then they can get into as much detail as he wants to.
Only one sheet.
One sheet of paper on the top.
So did you do a lot of drafting then?
No, I did the managing of getting it done and of getting into the details that they didn't want to deal with after they'd seen the summary.
I had to read every one of those papers before it went into them.
And then if they take whatever instruction they had with regard to that action after they had dealt with it, often I would take it in and actually present it to them verbally.
In fact, I say often, that was more the rule than the exception.
This meant that I had to prepare myself in that specific topic.
There had been hundreds of staff hours of work, staff officers' work, gone into it in many cases because it's not just the guy preparing it.
But he has to coordinate it with those who have an interest in it, not only in G-3 but
G1 personnel or G2 intelligence or G4 logistics.
And I felt a great responsibility that if I was going to go in there and present this for a decision that I understood it and that I presented it correctly.
No general can sit there and read every one of these papers that have all that background behind that top sheet.
So they'd want a briefing.
So they'd want a briefing and that was the
Many of these, of course, were very simple.
Some of them were very complex and very important.

But I could get so much of this out of their way and conserve the time of the staff officers who worked on it by preparing myself, taking in, presenting, and getting a decision, and I'd write out the decision to go back for implementation.
I'd write out the decision made as expressed by the general officer who made the decision.
Perhaps it was one he made a recommendation because it had to go on to the Chief of Staff, maybe the Secretary of the Army, maybe the Secretary of Defense, depending.
Some even to the President occasionally.

So anyway, I was just a flunky, but at the same time I got into the stream of information on this and knowledge and consideration on it by virtue of the fact that I was an administrator who was presenting the problems in many instances
to the decision-maker.

Now, in some of these very complex cases, it would be clear to me that I should not present it because it takes so much preparation, background, and knowledge on the subject that I would simply call the division chief concerned and request that they present it.
They present it, having dealt with it, by briefing
to the General and then set it up with the General.
Now did your opinion of the Pentagon and the workings of the Pentagon change before you went to the Pentagon and while you were there and after you left?
Did my opinion change?
Yeah.
What did you think of how the Army was run?
sort of a parallel to my description of going back to A&M on the staff.

You know, at a distance you respect higher authority and don't know the details and don't realize that there are some little fights and fusses and rough spots that you never see, but when you're there you see them.
But I was very proud of the effectiveness and efficiency of the Army staff.
The more I came to know it, the more I believed in it as a system, and it is a system.
Sure.
that we used was basically created with the Germans, you know.
And it's sound.
It's been used for years and years.
I do think that subsequently we've gotten off to excellence because we don't have a general staff system really anymore.

we have the whiz kids staff system the McNamara system we'll get to McNamara we'll give you a full chance it's confused the lines of action and staffing procedures so that well it's what adds these years to our getting where we want to go in my opinion now we'll get to McNamara we're going to talk about him he's very important I've heard that
The Pentagon consumes long hours.
Is that what you found?
Indeed.
Matter of fact, on this job I've just described to you, seldom would I get out of the I'd be there early before anybody had came in that office in the morning.
How early?
Oh, I'd usually be there by 7 or 7.30.
And rarely did I ever get out of there before 7 at night, sometimes later.
It might be interesting to mention
that the executive officer to whom I was assistant was then Colonel Harold K. Johnson, who became Chief of Staff of the Army.
So, I had some very good guidance, and he was doing the managing, and I was doing the flunky work in there and keeping that office going.
How was he as a leader?
Tremendous.
Tremendous.
if not the most admired man, one of the most in my career.
He, an interesting thing, he had one of the most brilliant minds, one of the most human personalities, and one of the most dedicated commitments to service anyone ever knew.
and very religious.
He was a victim of the death march at the time.
He was a prisoner of the Japanese through that whole ordeal, and he was liberated at the end of the war.
He was a very corresponding and strong man when he went in, but he came out stronger in character.
I'm sure he never had an idol

moment mentally during his captivity because he just maintained his sharpness and his vision and so well most people who went through that ordeal were damaged to some extent but not him and I've seen others who weren't who came out stronger too as a result of that so anyway he was a he was a fine mentor
He was chief staff during the Vietnam War.
Yeah.

You went from the Pentagon to the Army War College, and then you went right after that in November 1957 as a colonel to the Strategic Intelligence School and the Language School, in which you stayed for about a year and a half until June 1959 before you went to Yugoslavia.
Let's talk about the Intelligence School.
All right.
At the Army War College, as you're completing your year, you get your assignment, your next assignment.
They come up and tell you first before they issue the orders.
Well, they told me that I had been selected as military attache to Yugoslavia.
And I said, I don't want that job.
Really?
And they said, well, it's yours.
Why?
Why didn't you want it?
Well, in Venezuela, I had observed an attache at work, and he became a good friend.
And he was a very pleasant person, and I liked him.
I saw something of him later.
But he was military attach to Venezuela, and he was over to our mission frequently, and I didn't see that he had a job to do.

As it turns out, that's pretty much true when you're attach to an allied country or a very friendly country, but it's quite different in a country that's not that close to us, like Yugoslavia being a communist country and so forth and so on.
After all, the primary function of an attach is military intelligence.
particularly strategic intelligence.
In other words, the things that are going to be important for the long pull or for the longer range of time.
So anyway, I just didn't say much about it.
Of course, in my class were people who'd been in personnel and intelligence and in attach duty, and so I went around asking them, how do I get out of this?
Almost to a man they said, don't.
don't even try.

I thought, really, honestly, and I say I'm naive, but I thought that the Army only took volunteers for military out-of-shade duty because of the peculiar aspects of theyou're attached to an embassy, you see, and you're really on diplomatic status, and you're very heavily committed to a social calendar.
Sure.
Absolutely.
And this is the other thing.
That never appealed to me.
In fact, that, to me,
appeared to be a burden and a debilitator.

So I thought, and also in some posts, it used to be, it wasn't at this time, it used to be, and this kind of got into the knowledge of the position, that they'd select officers who had additional, you know, extra income, resources, because they'd spend more than they made.
Well, that wasn't true at the time I went on duty because in order to send whoever they wanted to,
Part of the reason, they provided the necessary allowances to cover those extra expenses.
But anyway, they said, don't try to get out.
First of all, you probably can't.
Secondly, if you try too hard, don't.
Or even if you do succeed, it's going to damage you.
It's going to damage your record, your assignment probability for the next assignment.
Not that people are going to be unfair, but you just declared that you're not willing to do what you're told to do.
You know that doesn't fit.
So anyway, it took a year and a half to prepare for that assignment, and that was only a two-year assignment.
And that seems extravagant.
It sure does.
And it is very expensive.
I bet.
And it really, and I recommended that it be made a three-year assignment to make it more cost effective.
Now, the reason I didn't extend is that, strangely enough, when I got on
post to do my two-year job if I didn't tell them within a month or so, as I recall, a very short period of time.
Well, obviously, if it takes a year and a half to prepare, they've got to know right away.
I didn't know whether I wanted to extend or not.
And it was a two-year assignment because it was not considered a desirable assignment.
It was, you know, rough on the family.
So anyway, that year and a half preparation included six months of strategic intelligence school.
In which you studied?
In which, uh,
We were oriented on really what the importance of strategic intelligence, how it's gathered, how it's put together, and what it means to the nation, to the Army.
Where was that school?
It was in Washington, and that was very valuable.
And it did, of course, have a period of time devoted to attache functions and how best to approach those.
You're your own boss, pretty much.
you know, profiting from the guidelines the Army gives and the experiences of others.
Then I went to the Army Language School to study the Yugoslav language, and that was absolutely essential because English is... You just can't get by.
You couldn't then, anyway.
You could not get that job done in English now.
There's just no way to do it.
